author: Gronbolar

print_settings.Notes:: Use 5 walls [perimeters] for strength.

description.text:
Improve cooling with a dual 5015 fan setup.

Pros:
-superior cooling
-no air dumping down on the part when you don't need it [PETG, TPU]
-20g lighter than the stock setup
-clear view of the nozzle, easy to clean up stray filament

Cons:
-exposed hot end. Keep kids and curious pets away.
-if you use Cura > Print Sequence > one at a time, the fans may crash into existing parts

What you need:
2 5015 radial fans
2 3x25mm nuts & bolts [nylon/metal]
rewiring materials [soldering iron, shrink wrap, 2-pin connectors...]
dial indicator with 8 or 9.5mm stem

Leveling the bed:
-heat the bed up to normal operating temperature
-press fit the dial indicator into the mount
-run the included level.gcode
-after homing there is a 10 second pause for zeroing the indicator
-there is a 5 second pause at each corner for adjustment
-it goes around twice
-tweak the gcode to match your workflow
***remove dial indicator before printing

This process levels the bed but does not set the correct distance between the nozzle and the bed. Test print to get the right height. Try using thingiverse.com/thing:2425796 for easy adjustment. Turn each knob an equal number of teeth to maintain a level bed.

*added the original Fusion 360 files.

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Use 5 walls [perimeters] for strength.
The part cooling fan clicks into the mount and is secured with a bolt. Attach the mount to the X carriage with the original hardware [M3 bolts]. Rewire the fans.

Most headphone stands seem to forget about the cable. So I designed my own with a hollow base to allow the cable to be hidden away.

The Image is shown with a custom logo but a solid top is provided so you can add any logo you want.
The top is a tight fit on the risers and it may require a little sanding, but the top support piece will cover all sanding marks. The Top support is not interference fitted. Due to tolerance stack up on my printer the support piece will require glue. I suggest you slide the support over the risers, attach the top, then add some glue near the top on the risers and slide the support up to match the top.

The accent pieces lightly snap together but I suggest a drop of superglue on all of the joints.

description.text:
I had this stand to hold my commonly used tools around my 3d printer.
A sharpened putty knife, 3/4" wood chisel, flush cutters, glue, deburring tools and a couple of scalpel blade knives.

A hook that folds flat when not in use.

The base has a cutout in it for a small magnet from Ace Hardware or the like.
The hook has an internal cavity for a magnet as well. Pause the print at 6mm, put a drop of super glue in and then drop the magnet in. Then resume the print.

A nail with the head cut off is used as the pin.

I provided a hook without a logo.

author: nuggyblake

title: Jig Saw Handle With Deposit For Blades
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Handle for T-shape jig saw blades, with blade magazine

03/22/2018: New version where the size of the saw blade socket has been corrected to the size of the Bosch blades. Now it fits perfectly. The saw body is also available in one piece, not divided. Soon I will publish more improvements (screw cap, etc.).

This is a handle for attaching jigsaw blades with a hole inside to store up to 10 blades (depending on thickness).

The wedge jaw and sliding clamp system provides optimum blade grip, preventing the blade from moving when sawing.

The design has been made to be printed on ABS.

Before printing, see the printing instructions.

To avoid the use of difficult to remove substrates, the handle is printed in two halves and then glued with PVC glue or by joining the two parts together and applying acetone to the joint. It will penetrate by capillary action by solidly joining the two pieces.

Before mounting, it may be necessary to sand the front of the handle until the clamp slips off effortlessly.

To assemble the cover, insert the two hooks with the protrusion facing outwards into the restangular holes of the cover, sticking them to the cover as indicated above. They must be slightly divergent from the cover.

In order to obtain an optimum grip on the saw, it is necessary to stick sandpaper grains in the jaw and inside the hole where the saw is embedded.

To achieve this, soak a few pieces of sandpaper (with fabric backing) in water (Sand Image 1). In a few minutes the "sand" will be detached from the fabric (Sand 2). Remove the pieces of cloth, rinse the sand and throw the water away. The sand will remain at the bottom of the container. Put it to dry. (Image Sand 3)

Take the jaw, soak the underside (the non-angled side) with acetone to soften the ABS. Add more acetone if it evaporates. Repeat for 30 seconds. Sprinkle the sand on this face and press a little to make it stick, remove the sand that has not stuck and flatten it by pressing with a saw blade. Repeat the operation with the other side on the handle, where the cradle is seated. Take care that the sand does not stick to the walls and only to the bottom. If this runs, remove the sand from the walls before it dries (Sand Image 4).

The Assembly image shows how to mount a saw on the handle.

Depending on the thickness of the mounted saw, the clamp may not go all the way, but the saw will be securely fastened. It has been tested with 0.8 to 1.5 mm thick saws.

A slightly longer clamp design has been included for use if you don't want to use the sanding trick, but the saw's grip will be worse.

Mango para sierras de caladora de bástago en T, con depósito de hojas

Se trata de un mango para acoplar hojas de sierra caladora con un hueco en el interior para guardar hasta 10 hojas (dependiendo del grosor).

Con el sistema de mordaza en cuña y abrazadera deslizante se proporciona un agarre óptimo de la hoja, impidiendo que esta se mueva al serrar.

El diseño se ha hecho para ser impreso en ABS.

Antes de imprimir, ver las instrucciones de impresión.

Para evitar el uso de soportes difíciles de retirar, el mango se imprime en dos mitades que luego hay que pegar con pegamento de PVC o uniendo las dos partes y poniendo acetona en la unión. Esta penetrará por capilaridad uniendo las dos piezas sólidamente.

Antes del montaje, puede ser necesario lijar la parte delantera del mango hasta que la abrazadera se deslice sin esfuerzo.

Para montar la tapa, insertar los dos ganchos con el resalte hacia fuera en los huecos restangulares de la tapa, pegandolos a esta de la forma antes indicada. Deben quedar de forma ligeramente divergente con respecto a la tapa.

Para conseguir un agarre óptimo de la sierra, es necesario pegar granos de lija en la mordaza y en el interior del hueco donde va encastrada la sierra.

Para conseguirlo, poner en remojo con agua unos trozos de papel de lija del número 40 (con soporte de tela)(Imagen Sand 1). En unos minutos la "arena" se habrá desprendido de la tela (Imagen Sand 2). Retirar los trozos de tela, enjuagar la arena y tirar el agua. La arena quedará en el fondo del recipiente. Ponerla a secar. (Imagen Sand 3)

Tomar la mordaza, empapar la cara inferior (la cara no inclinada) con acetona para que se reblandezca el ABS. Poner más acetona si ésta se evapora. Repetir durante 30 segundos. Espolvorear la arena sobre esa cara y presionar un poco para que se adhiera, retirar la arena que no se ha pegado y aplanar presionando con el bástago de una hoja de sierra. Repetir la operación con la otra cara en el mango, donse se asienta el bástago. Cuidar que la arena no se pegue en las paredes y lo haga solo en el fondo. Si esto scurre, retirar la arena de las paredes antes de que se seque (Imagen Sand 4).

La imagen Assembly muestra cómo montar una sierra en el mango.

Según el grosor de la sierra montada, la abrazadera puede que no llegue hasta el final, pero la sierra quedará bien sujeta. Se ha probado con sierras de 0,8 a 1,5 mm de grosor.

Se ha incluido un diseño de mordaza un poco más largo para usarla si no se desea usar el truco de la lija, pero el agarre de la sierra será peor.

title: Oculus Rift - Top Strap Cable Guide

description.text:
As I have the Oculus' cable routed through the ceiling with pulleys, I wanted the cable to exit from top strap (centered) towards the back.

After some tinkering and tests I designed this object, better explained by just looking at the attached photos.

The zip in the back attachment is there to prevent the cable from sliding back... ugly hack I know...

  • Front black attachement is this one: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1686552

title: Mobile phone micro usb phone stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a stand for the Samsung Galaxy S7 mobile phone. It uses a worn cable for powering/charging the phone while it is docked. Note, the USB cord I used in this design has no plastic cover at the micro USB side (that was one of the reasons for designing this stand).

The stand is unfortunately at a bit steep angle but can support a phone. I added the extra support that is interlockable for lowering the angle. It works great!

Printer:

TEVO Tarantula

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

5-20%

Notes:

I printed the stand first without thinking about the center point of gravity of the phone. As it happens to be, the phone could stand in the original stand but the slightest touch would make it tip over. For that reason I designed the extra wedge platform wich interlocks directly into the cable grove.

IMPORTANT

This design utilizes a micro usb cord that has lost its plastic cover.

Step 1

Print all the parts and remove any supports and rafts. I printed mine at 204 C nozzle and 60 C bed with PLA.

You will need two of the clamps for apparent reasons ;)

Step 2

Take a micro USB without cover and push it through the extra base and the stand. Attach the clamps to the cord and fit it into place.

Step 3

Attach the extra base to the stand and you have a nice dock for your Samsung S7.

Enjoy

Fusion 360

I am rather new to designing and 3d software and I took this project as a learning experiance. The process of designing is far from perfect but the finished product is great :)

description.text:
Replacement microwave handle that has a nice inside contour that is easy to grip - nicer than original I'm told. Hole spacing is 252mm. Groves around mounting holes are for reinforcement.

Prints nicely on it's side w/o support, at least 4 walls and 10% infill. STEP file included. Use MicrowaveHandleTest stl to dial in printing overhangs and bed adhesion.

I also added 'EZ' version of the handle. I did not print this one, however the only difference is less steep overhangs which maybe easier to print for some. It also features internal voids to reinforce the area around attachment point.

Note that original GE handle had two holes and area around each hole was raised. I modeled replacement w/o those features to be able to print w/o support and so it would fit other similar microwaves.

title: Autolevel plate for CTC PI3 Pro B

description.text:
Plate for mounting an autolevel inductive sensor on a CTC PI3 Pro B.

The sensor is an inductive probe SN04-N.

You will need to mod the GT2560 motherboard to connect it to the sensor. Put a male pin on the 5v pad, and solder right angle male pin to the mosfet GND (see photo). The sensor line goes to the bottom pin on z-max. You will need Repetier firmware instead of Marlin.

You will need two 50mm M3 screws to reach to the other side of the extruder plate.

TinkerCad
GIMP
InkScape
S3D

Steps to reproduce your own:
  • install Inkscape
    http://www.inkscape.org/
  • install textex Inkscape extension
    http://pav.iki.fi/software/textext/
  • install inkscape2openscad Inkscape extension
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25036
    • Then open Inkscape and select:
    Extensions -> Render -> LaTeX formula...
    Write your formula; the one in this keychain is:
    (x^2+(y-\sqrt[3]{x^2})^2=1)
    that is the one that draws an heart.
    Then export your formula to openscad:
    Extensions -> Generate from Path -> Paths to OpenSCAD... Now you can open the formula on OpenSCAD, and modify it as you like! (original equation and heart image come from a "I fu**ing love science" fb post) Here a verbose howto:
    http://www.instructables.com/id/Math-Formula-to-3D-printable-object/

title: Vertex K8400 Heated Bed Drilling Guides

description.text:
When adding a heated bed to a Velleman Vertex K8400, an extra power supply and a heated bed expansion module are needed. I wanted to be sure that I got the holes in the right place when drilling, so I designed these template guides to match the screw holes on the PSU and expansion modules accordingly.

The PSU drilling guide matches a JCPower JC-240-24 Chassis Mount power supply (24V, 10A)
The Heated Bed Expansion Module drilling guide is for the Board210A-style MOSFET RAMPS upgrade.

I made a video about adding the heated bed to my vertex, so you if you're thikning about using these drilling guides, you might like to take a look at how I modded my printer.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yFHWBVa4O94

There's a new version of this with interchangeable clamps to hold a wider variety of figures!
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2493560

I normally use old Chessex paint pots with washers glued to the tops to hold my miniatures while painting. There's a magnet glued to the base of the mini to make storing them easier, which also makes them stick nicely to the top of the pot. This works fine for plastic figures and small metal ones, but once you get past a certain size the magnet really doesn't do the trick. So I wanted something the size and shape of one of my old Chessex pots, that would physically clamp a figure. A couple of revisions later and here we are.

In addition to the printed parts included in this file you will need:
1 x M3 hex nut
1 x M3x35 round head machine screw
4 x #6 x 1/2 wood screw (M3.5 x 12)
1 x 16mm marble
2 x bits of rubber

I didn't have any marbles, so I used one of the bearings out of the CV joints of an '89 VW Fox, which I did have. I had an odd childhood.

The bits of rubber go on either side of the bearing and keep the thing from moving. The nut and bolt go through the clamp to tighten it together and the wood screws go in the holes on top. The nut hole is slightly tapered so it should hold it in place once you've used it the first time. You can also carefully drip some glue down there to keep the little bastard from falling out.

Right now this will only hold 25mm round and square bases, but I'm working on a new design that will be able to hold a wider variety.

author: Basmaalmahmoud

title: Settlers of Catan Storage Box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
There were a few things I didn't like about the original storage box. The primary reason for this remix is to remove all the spacer rings you need to print with the original. All those extra parts, extra plastic, and the extra time it took to setup/break down the game were just not needed.

So first and foremost I got rid of all the spacers and created shelves that the pieces slide into. They are all uniform and labeled, the only exception are the ports which have a couple different heights. I printed the pieces as pictured in the original post with the exception of no houses on the brick pieces. The obvious caveat being this box isn't modular so you'll need to print the same pieces.

I also changed the peg holes because they were too loose. I changed the pieces box because we prefer to play the random tileset which means you need the original game pieces to setup the board. I removed the resource card holder and used that space to hold the original pieces as pictured.

Everything fits in the original top, and in the same footprint as the original design. In the future I may come up with a more modular, or universal design to allow for different printed pieces, but for now this will do.

Small edit, I took a moment and layed the box halves down how they should be printed instead of upright how I designed them. Now everything should print as is.

print_settings.Notes:: The cut-out for where the PSU sits needs supports so that it can print properly. Because the supports are quite tall and have a tendency to get clipped by the hot end, I'd recommend printing this with a 5mm brim to keep the support firmly pinned to the build plate. Because PLA is quite a hard plastic it has a tendency to rattle a bit when it's in the printer. I'd recommend using PETG for it's sound damping properties.

title: Vertex K8400 Trash Can with PSU Cutout

description.text:
As part of a little project to add a heated bed to my Vertex printer, I added an extra PSU which meant that Ekdahl's awesome little mini Trash Can would no longer fit. This is a redesign with a cut-out made so that it can fit around the extra power supply.

You see a video of how I added the heatbed to my printer. I also made some drilling guides (also on Thingiverse) to help me get the screw holes for everything in the correct place.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yFHWBVa4O94

description.text:
I was getting tired of interlocking smaller bases together for large rectangular type building so I decided to simplify the process and create a 4 inch by 3 inch openlock base, something I couldn't find in the standard and nonstandard sets. Since I had created the base, I thought I might as well provide my wooden floor on this type of base as well. Something I used in my horse stable without a base located here. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2487144.
There is also a top cap wooden floor of 4x3 inch if you want to use another style base. If going to a "Wyloch" (true tile) style size, you will need to resize the top cap floor to 125% of original size.
You can get the openlock clip here. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1833963

description.text:
I built this as part of a larger rebuild of my Tevo Tarantula. It is still a work in progress, but I thought I would share this iteration for anyone that might be able to use it.

This mount is designed to allow the power supply to stand vertically with the terminals safely covered. This takes up a smaller footprint around the printer. There is a provision for a power switch/IEC connector (https://www.amazon.com/Inlet-Module-Switch-Socket-IEC320/dp/B00F4MFMXE). There are holes on the bottom to mount it to your base as well as holes on one side to mount to the vertical extrusion of the gantry. There are two 8mm holes for the wiring to exit through, as well as a provision for a 4mm bolt to be used as a strain relief.

UPDATE 2017-09-03: I have updated the base so that it stands out away from the 2020 by 5mm. This was necessary to allow the Z wheels to pass when going up and down. I have also added the top bracket. This helps secure the PS so it doesn't fall out. It also makes the gantry more stable Win-win!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

1.5mm-2.5mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I sliced it with S3d and used variable processes to change the print height to 1.5mm wherever there were holes or arches. The rest of it was printed at 2.5mm. I used eSun black PLA at 210/55 celsius. I used custom supports for the large window where the IEC connector goes.

The top is printed upright, so there will need to be supports inside. Sorry about that :/

This can be mounted directly to your gantry or screwed down to a table surface. Mount the case, and then run your wires to the power supply. Install the IEC/Switch, and fit the power supply into the top.

Put a 4mm screw into the hole between the cable openings, and then zip tie the wiring to the bolt. This will give you a bit of a strain relief for your cables.

There are currently no mounting holes for the supply (as this is still a work in progress) but mine has fit snuggly into the printed part. I intend to eventually make a top bracket to fix it all into place. For now this should work as is for most people.

The big picture

This is part of a larger rebuild, and I intend to add/edit this model as needed. My rebuild is inspired by the actual Prusa (which the Tevo is nothing like). There will be other parts involved which I will share as I complete them.

Here is my Raspberry Pi case for my Raspberry Pi 2, I think it will probably fit the Raspberry Pi 3 as well. It is an economical print and therefore quite quick to print out.

It is a snap shut design, with push in feet, the tolerances are quite tight but it fits and snaps together perfectly with a hardly visible seem.

To snap it shut, squeeze the top and bottom together at the corners,print 4 feet off and push the feet in, you may need to use a bit of force. Dont snap it together without the Pi in because once its snapped together its quite hard to split again.

Oh yeah, you will probably need to rotate the parts to print, should be printed on the bottom of the bottom and top of the top

comments.text: I'm about to do a redesign and put up a warning on the blog saying not to build this version.  I've managed to kill two Imp explorer boards with this design.  The problem is that the various designs for a solar shield have failed to provide sufficient protection for blown raindrops.  If the humidity sensor actually gets wet, it will fail.    The trick is to have sufficient air flow that when the sun is out you don't have a solar oven, but when it rains the sensors don't get flooded.   I've got some ideas, but it may be another rev or two before I'd recommend building this.

Initial release of my GameCube digital port plug.

A word of warning this part requires extremely fine levels of detail printing, I had to have my prototype produced with a print company.

The pins I used inside this connector are pulled from a PCI connector, you can find them on eBay, they are fairly inexpensive. The pins slide into the connector and require a small amount of force to press into the spot they seat into. You may need to pop the front edge of the pin into the slot at the front of the connector.

A few notes on the design, I am using 0.5mm pins to contact a 1.0mm pad, there really isn't any reason to draw a large amount of current through this port so the thinner pins should not be an issue. The design has not yet been tested with any video replacement solution yet.

description.text: My cheap Chinese CNC spindle is 55mm in the middle and the top is even 56.6mm so I had to make the hole in this part 56mm to make it all fit.

I designed this back in 2013. It is incomplete, but its a good start. There is currently no way to constrain the planet gears in the carrier planets axially. And although we could constrain the ring gears together by forced fit pins, its not ideal and might be pretty difficult to do. The gear teeth on the planet gears and the ring gears are actual involute curves modeled with splines. So if printed with good settings, they should roll fairly well. Each stage is a 4:1 ratio, and I designed them to be stackable - like there is a 16:1 ratio shown in the picture. I haven't actually tried printing it because the design isn't complete but I thought I'd post it so you guys can try. Or if you want to scavenge it for gears. Thanks!

remixed_from.author: ndupont
remixed_from.title: Tevo Tarantula Y axis motor rigidity spacers (3mm)

title: Tevo Tarantula X axis rigidity brackets

description.text:
Excellent rigidity, the lightweight way. Only 15 grams for the 2 parts

The Tevo Tarantula only holds the X motor and idler pulleys by one side of the X profile, leading to bending of the acrylic brackets when tension is applied on the belt. Motor side being the worst.

Required parts

  • Motor side requires 4 M3x35mm allen screws and 4 sets of 3mm spacers,like on the Y axis : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2491039
  • Idler side requires 2 M5x25mm allen screws, and 4 5mm spacers, also like on the front side of the Y axis : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2393545
  • Each side needs : 2 M4 allen screws with T-nuts and washers

I found the screws on eBay, "M335mm A2 304 STAINLESS STEEL ALLEN BOLT" and "M535mm A2 304 STAINLESS STEEL ALLEN BOLT"

One STL contains the 2 parts kit, but distinct files are also provided for motor and idler sides.

Print with 30% infill, with no brim or supports. Not too hot or you'll have to drill the 3mm, 4mm and 5mm holes after print.

Installation of the motor-side

  • Start with the fully functionnal Tarantula and don't remove anything yet.
  • Remove the M3 screw holding the idler pulley
  • Fit the M4 screws, with washer and t-nuts on the additional bracket
  • Fit a M3x35mm screw with a plastic washer and a spacer, then the pulley on the bracket
  • Insert the belt and align with the motor as well as the X rail (t-nuts have to be horizonal)
  • Install the second 5.5mm spacer and push the screw to the motor through the acrylic bracket
  • Gently tighten the M3 screw as well as the M4/t-nuts, just to rotate them in lock position
  • Insert the 3 remaining M3x35mm screws in the 3 other holes, in order to align the bracket by pushing the end in to original screw heads
  • Align the bracket with the motor and lock the M4/t-nuts. Then remove the 3 M3 screws
  • We'll continue clockwise with the bottom-right screw, that can be removed by inserting the 3mm allen wrench though the 3mm hole of the additional bracket. Remove the washer as well (if present).
  • Fit a plastic washer on a M3x35 screw, then through the bracket, and place a 5.5mm spacer, then a 9mm tube, followed by a second 5.5mm spacer.
  • Finally push the screw in the original acrylic part, and tighten gently but firmly (enough to prevent any movement of the stepper motor)
  • Repeat with the bottom left and finally top left screws
  • Thighten the M3 screws for good, then the M4/t-nuts.

title: Sphere Ice Maker Mold A
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Makes a single 1.5 inch spherical chunk of ice.

Easy to print, make walls/top/bottom at least 1.2mm to 2mm thick.

Fill one of two ways; either fill the bottom half over a sink then put the top on then pour excess water out, or put the top on then fill through the hole. Do not fill to the entire sphere area with water, allow some empty space for water to expand as it turns into ice, otherwise you could end up cracking the mold.

Print in a food safe material.

comments.text: It doesn't matter what you print it in, the layers aren't washable and bacteria can grow there. Just be careful, print at the finest layer height you can and maybe sand the inside. Or print a high temp material and maybe boil it every once in a while.
comments.author: Sterminare

comments.text: Not sure if you'd have to worry about bacteria with just making ice.  They sell water distillers with water holding containers that can't even be opened, to best you could hope for is pouring in soapy water and shaking it around.  So if bacteria isn't a huge problem there, then it wouldn't be for icy stuff.  Instead of boiling, one could also just give it a nice salt water soak overnight once a month.  One could also use a non toxic food safe paint/epoxy.

title: Fastwheel F0 Scooter additional handlebars for child
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are additional handlebars I've printed for my son to ride our electric scooter together, so he could feel more comfortable holding on to them instead of steering rod.

Those are modeled for Fastwheel F0 scooter but may fit others, rod diameter is 28.5mm and has an anti-spinning pin on the back so the handlebars do not rotate. Handlebars are 25mm diameter for child's hands.

Construction is very sturdy, I think I've overdone it a bit, but that`s definitely good for safety. I printed it with PETG and it seems indestructible =)

You need 2x M8x70 bolts, 2x M6x30 bolts (I used 40mm on photos, they are a bit longer than needed) and 2+2 nuts for them. Handles are printed in parts and then glued together (for higher strength). Nuts are located inside handlebars, the bolt goes from the inner part of rod clamp and tightened with a socket wrench. Special pins on the top and the bottom of the handlebars do not allow them to rotate when in place. The clamp itself is designed not to open freely on rod and parts must be slide one into other on the rod from top to bottom.

UPDATE: 2017-09-15 some adjustments to enhance durability and added cutouts for halfs fixing bolts

The Covenant Brute Shot, sliced up and ready to print! Every piece is scaled according to the Official Halo Visual Guide, so this is a 100% accurate prop! I've added a build guide that labels the parts and where they go (since there's a lot) and arranged each piece to minimize overhang and use of support material. just download and print!

Want to see more? visit my thingiverse page to see my other models!

RECOMMENDED SETTINGS:
Quality: medium to high (depending on your patience)
Support material: minimal
Infill: 5-10% (to save time/filament)

A simple spindle holder - one moving part, prints in 3 pieces.

Made for a FLSUN Kossel Delta.

Step 1

Push the pin into the roller. Glue if place if necessary. Depending on your printer it may just fit in place.

Step 2

Attach the mount low on a vertical beam using an M4 nut and bolt.

Step 3

Place the roller on the base.

Step 4

Attach the extruder above the spool holder, ensuring there's enough space for a large spool.

Step 5

Shorten your bowden tube if it's excessively long. (If your extruder was previously top-mounted, you can cut it a little shorter. Less tube = less friction, I assume.)

This time it's shoe company logos. I included the .SVG files I used to create the .STL files with. As always feel free to use this in anyway you please and if you come up with a great design please take all the credit. Just doing this to pass the time.

print_settings.Notes:: The dice are easy to print using standard parameters.  One can print one by one or print an array of 16 dice.

description.text:
Four slightly different types of dice, made for teachers. Each one is 20mm^3. The dents are made using about 45-degree cones for easy printing. This is also a simple starting project for someone to learn about 3D design-- cube, sphere, cones, alignment, cut, and intersections. Have fun!

I initially made these dice without considering the traditional sum-of-seven configuration (6 and 1 are on opposite sides). I am not mathematically convinced that the numbers have to be arranged that way for fairness beyond the balance of numbers. Theoretically, the one (1) hole should be much bigger to balance the holes on the opposite side. Physically, I think we might need to balance the center of mass. Anyway, I added a traditional set. Thanks for the feedback and support.

For all realistic purposes, they should be just fine.    Now, is there any physical or mathematical  reason that 1 must be on the opposite of 6? If so, I would like to know it. description.text:
I designed this one because my brother was asking for some pot for carrying some cigarettes that prevents smell going out.

I made two different sizes and used some o-rings to prevent smell and tobacco going out.
For the little model I'm using 9.5x12.7mm o-ring.
For the big model I'm using 19.1x23.8mm o-ring.
I'm sure other o-ring can be used, print it and visit your local store to see what they have.

I would like to thank you to Dan Kirshner for sharing his thread library that produces standardized ISO threads. You can find it here http://dkprojects.net/openscad-threads/

It can be used for many other things more.

Use, share and enjoy the design!

title: Sphere Ice Maker Mold B
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Makes a single 1.5 inch spherical chunk of ice.

Easy to print, make walls/top/bottom at least 1.2mm to 2mm thick.

Fill one of two ways; either fill the bottom half over a sink then put the top on then pour excess water out, or put the top on then fill through the hole. Do not fill to the entire sphere area with water, allow some empty space for water to expand as it turns into ice, otherwise you could end up cracking the mold.

Includes a plug for the top hole. You don't really need it, but it's there for those that want it.

For easy ice removal, twist the top and pull open.

Print in a food safe material.

author: prowinski

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/lohdqPSyrll

Edit 09/30/17: Updated Container Skirt, Skirt detail, Cap and added Container Static Connector. The first 3 were updated to give a little bit better tolerances when printed.

When I made the first Hogdrogen container (now deleted) it was with almost no knowledge of how Fusion 360 worked and the last 3D modelling program I had used being Maya in like 2008. So while I did like it it had some problems mainly with user friendliness and some model issues. I should note this is my third ever 3D model EVER so it probably has tons of problems.

  • There were some weird irregularities in the main container and I had no clue why
  • Some bits were combined into a single body which made painting the final product harder.
  • Extremely unfriendly in terms of putting together. Nothing to guide bits together to make sure it was symmetrical or whatnot.

So with these in mind I went back to the drawing board and redid everything 100%. Nothing is reused at all. Now the container is properly measured and defined (instead of eyeballing it) and is made out of 8 parts. There are also guide bits that print out attached (so you essentially can put this together almost without any glue at all) so everything lines up how they should. HOWEVER I do not know how to take into account tolerances while modelling so you will almost assuredly have to sand the bits down a tiny bit. First and foremost this was designed by a cosplayer for cosplay purposes. It is meant to be printed, sanded and painted. This is not meant to be printed and to be displayed as is thus things may not fight together out of the printer at all without sanding.

Some print notes:

  • Container cap should be flipped 180 degrees and then you can avoid supports
  • Container Skirt Detail x2 should be flipped backwards 45 degrees and then you can avoid supports
  • Almost everything else will need SOME supports due to the overhangs.
  • Container flexible is meant to be printed in a TPU to make it functional. I don't plan on adding a static bit but if you want to go ahead.

There's nothing else I can really think of to add. This was a WIP but I have finished everything I want and will call it quits.

License set to what it is as I dont mind people taking it and adding bits (like the static park aforementioned) but I don't want a company to download my files and sell the prop for a mint. I'd rather people be able to have this for free. There are many services out there that will let you print a file for a certain sum, that I have no problem with.

Below are the layer views from Cura. I used the Prusa i3 Mk 2 preset (mostly for the build plate volume, I don't own a 3D printer at this time). The very first picture is the estimates Cura 2.6.2 gave on time, material, weight and whether I used supports or not. Everything was set to 20% infill at 0.2mm height.

title: Mine Truck
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Encouraged by the success of my Mine Trolley Prop for stop motion project, I decided to design some wagons to fit the Mine Trolley. The3D printed model presented here is a chassis that can be fitted with any other sort of top. For this first version, I just a made simple flat-deck using ice-block sticks.

The overall dimensions are 65mm wide x 120mm long x 32mm tall. The track gauge is about 38mm. The wheels have reasonably wide flanges and so can ride on rails up to about 40mm between rail centrelines.

The deck on top was made from iceblock sticks stuck together with PVA glue with a thin cardboard strip around the edge. Easy to make with a hacksaw and sandpaper. The iceblock sticks were painted with a sepia coloured brown acrylic house paint without undercoat. This allowed the paint to penetrate the wood nicely and give an aged stained look. I have not included an STL for this part seeing as it is so simple to construct anyway.

Things you will need in addition to the printed bits;

  • 2 x Ø4mm rods of some sort for the axles. These are cut to 55mm long. I used dowel.
  • Popsicle sticks for the deck.
  • Glue. I use an epoxy glue, buy anything without too much flexibility will work.
  • Any other structures you would like to add to it. For instance I shall build a tank truck at some stage. This may be made with something like a repurposed plastic container with some wire detailing for things like hand-rails.

In the model shown here, the buffer channel sections were cardboard rather than being 3D Printed. This gave a slightly more rugged look. The original digital model and all STLs include these channel sections as you can see in the exploded view below.

There are quite a few pieces in this project. The .pdf in the downloads has some assembly suggestions.

Incidentally, the images shown here with the Mine Truck loaded with stuff feature a couple of barrels. These are scaled up prints of Dutchmogul's dungeon Delving Decor: Medieval Barrels.

Have fun with this.

More stuff over at Youmagine - www.youmagine.com - mine truck.

Threads (especially this small) need as much detail as possible, so you need the set the layer height low.

I redesigned Kart5a's file in 123D Design, but without teeth. I then took a scaled down version of the screw in https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:274403 and made it a hole in the previously mentioned file with TinkerCad.

author: Precision3DPrinting

title: MiniBox for mini 360 DC/DC buck down converter

description.text:
If you own one of those mini-360 DC to DC buck down converter (say to convert from 12vdc to 5vdc) and look for something to protect the little bugger, then this mini-box is for you.
I used this mini-360 to tap 12vdc off my Mosfet and feed 5vdc to my 8mm auto-bed leveling sensor (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008FZC8F2/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1). It worked quite well without draining any voltage off the Anet A8 main board.

Wiring:
I connected the leveling sensor's brown wire to the 5vdc (output end) of the mini-360. I tied both the sensor blue wire and the mini-360 output ground together and connected those to the leftmost pin of the Z end-stop. I did not use the Z end-stop middle pin (it's the main board's 5vdc that many recommended to use and I didn't like to take power off the board). The sensor's black wire, which is signal, was connected to the right-most pin of the Z end-stop.

Printed using 50mms speed, 50% infill, 200deg extruder, 60 deg hotbed using PLA 1.75mm, support generation needed.
Enjoy.

description.text: Wider Whirlpool storage tray brackets. Replaces existing brackets that were too narrow, as a result the storage tray would fall of the bracket rails. Print the 2x brackets flat. Source your own screws.

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Depending on your printer, you may or may not need supports for the overhang.

Designed to fit Armattan Chameleon 19x4mm arm with 3mm hole for antenna tube.

Borrowing the idea of zip tie + heat shrink that I've liked but always had shit luck by having antennas mutilated in props or zip ties breaking off.
This tries to fix the problem by having stiffer supports that should be easily replaceable and being serviceable without fiddling with shrink tubes.

Update:
I was impressed how well this design survived crashes, so I took a second attempt at tinkercad and made much more cleaner version with tube angles a bit closer to that optimal 90 degrees.

Mirror the upgraded part in slicer to get the second side.
Best printed with PETG or something similiar flipped sideways. Tolerances are quite tight, so some minor filing and drilling is probably needed to achieve tight snap fit.

description.text:
If you've ever tried designing a mounting component before, you've had to think a little bit about the compromises between using a durable, hard plastic like PETG or ABS and a flexible, rubbery plastic like TPU or TPE. Picking a hard plastic means that your tolerances must be just right for the part holding your device -- too small and your device won't fit; too big, and your device device will fly out at the first sign of trouble. Picking a soft plastic means that your device can be cozily and safely encased in the embrace of a nice rubbery plastic, but your mount might flop around or worse -- tear or crack when put under strain. This component is designed to let you forget about that compromise and instead just use each plastic for the job it is designed for.

This is a mounting system that allows you to use a hard plastic like PETG or ABS for the durable mounting components, while using a flexible plastic like TPU or TPE for the part holding your device. It's based around a 20mm plastic pin with a 30mm flange that sits snugly in an inset in your flexible part, and a 30mm cup that the pin inserts into. When properly assembled and tightened, this creates a sandwich between the flange of the pin component, the flexible part, and the rim of the cup component, allowing you to have wide-strong attachment to your flexible part without sacrificing the strength of your mounting components.

I originally designed this for use with my Baofeng UV5R Mount, but do plan to use the same mounting system for a few other things, too.

Also pictured above: GoPro Handlebar Mount (M6 / Captive nut) (Not required)

Notes:

This model is composed of two parts:

  • The "Pin" (inner, male)
  • The "Cup" (outer, female)

and requires two extra parts:

  • One 15mm M6 Bolt (up to 17mm will work)
  • One M6 Locking Nut

The M6 locking nut is captive in the design of the cup, and introduces two challenges for you if you've never printed a part having a metal insert before:

  • You'll need to ensure that support material is not generated filling the position in which the nut will reside. This is easy to do in Simplify3d, but I'm not sure how such a thing is accomplished using Cura.
  • You will need to pause your print at the right time so you can insert the locking nut at the layer right before the nut is covered. The instructions for this will vary depending upon what kind of printer you are using and whether it is printing from an SD card or using a tool like OctoPrint, but you can find a variety of tutorial videos on youtube to help you solve this problem.

To assemble, in case it isn't obvious, you:

  1. Insert the pin through the hole in your flexible part such that the rim fits into the provided indentation.
  2. Place the cup over the protruding pin.
  3. Insert the 15mm M6 bolt through the hole in the pin and tighten until secure.

Good luck!
1/2 nuts

description.text:
Truncated octahedra, truncated cuboctahedra, and cubes pack together in the ratio 1:1:3 to fill space. Here are a number of polyhedra, taken from the packing, which can be used for study and amusement. The edge lengths of the faces are the same as those used for the blocks derived from the packing of truncated octahedra. thing:2479574 - Truncated Octahedra as Children's Blocks

A simple representation of the packing uses a half truncated octahedral cage - "block_six.stl" and a truncated cuboctahedron - "basic_t_cuboctahedron.stl". Two half cages completely surround the truncated cuboctahedron illustrating the packing. See image above.

Six other combinations of the three polyhedra are provided. There are many ways to join them together to fill space. For example a checker board arrangement of "block_twenty.stl" and "block_four.stl" makes layers which nest layers of truncated cuboctahedra.

OpenSCAD code is included.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Notes:

Many of the blocks require a little support.

The packing resembles the space filling packing of truncated octahedra - see thing:2479574. One can describe the packing of truncated octahedra as being composed of layers of octahedra joined by their square faces. When alternate layers are translated in 3 directions by half the distance between square faces they nest together to fill space.

This packing can also be described as containing two layers; here the layers are different. One layer is composed of truncated cuboctahedra joined by their octagonal faces. The second layer contains truncated octahedra, the square faces do not join together directly but are pushed apart by cubes. The two layers nest to fill space.

print_settings.Notes:: Pictured parts are printed in Das Filament PLA at 210°C/50°C on the Creality CR-10.

title: CR-10 Z-Axis Manual Adjustment Knob (also CR-10 mini, Hictop, Tevo Tornado)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
#ZKNOB
This two piece part replaces and adds to the acrylic stock cover on the Creality CR-10's Z-axis lead screw; It lets you manually control the hot end up and down (when steppers are disabled), which I have found to be VERY handy at times. For example when you're loading filament, stopping a failing print or first layer, you can easily lift the hot end by hand to give you more working space and a better view of the piece.

I have now also added a bigger version. This way it takes less spinning to manually up and down the hotend. Easily fluently movable with just one finger. (09-15-2018)

VIDEOS
A simple quick and dirty demonstration by me of how the knob works:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yPHjmhsJESk

And a more professional video by Chuck Hellebuyck on how to install the knob (and some other useful CR-10 (mini) mods) on Filament Friday: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qDG_C5y-psU&t=3m23s (3 minnutes and 23 seconds in).

UPDATES & HELPFUL COMMENTS

FIX (as of 02/10/2018)
Thanks to user wonkoderverstaendige I found out there was a tiny (but real) problem with the file of the big version. Basically the knob floated 0.002mm above the stem, which only caused a problem when sliced in particular way, but it had definitely a weak spot. So if yours snapped at any point, this is probably why. You should have no problems with the fixed file anymore. Sorry for the inconvenience if it got you frustrated!

10/28/2017
Pemic: "The knob works also for the Tevo Tornado. The stock cover is not necessary. To gain a little space on the upper side of the spindle, you have to pull the Z stepper axle a little it out of the coppler."

10/28/2017
Fort_Design: "I just wanted to let you know that this design will not fit the Anet E10. Mainly because the housing of the upper bearing on the E10 is closed on top. One would have to redesign these housings. Diameter of the spindle on Anet E10 is 8mm."

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Print the knob upside down. No supports needed.

I used 3 perimiters and a 30% infill, but you could go higher for extra strength. I've been using mine on a daily basis for months now and I haven't had any problems yet.

Pictured parts are printed in Das Filament PLA at 210°C/50°C on the Creality CR-10.

Just swap the acrylic stock part with the freshly printed cover plate, using the stock screws. The knob then simply screws onto the lead screw until it's snug enough to let you control both up and down movements with it.

title: One piece Heatsink Spacer for fan 30mm

description.text:
So I designed this one piece heatsink spacer for a 30 mm fan that is used to cool the
motor down. The issue is when one attempts to set up the heatsink fan they usually
come with four spacers that is usually position between the fan and the heat sink
itself there is a possibility that one of these spacers could be lost and as I was
configuring it it was very annoying to me so I decided to design this one piece
heat sink spacer to address that issue in to make things easier for a hobbyist to
figure his or hers heatsink fan up without too much of a fuss. If you wish to download
this file depending on your 3D printer you may have to do some sanding otherwise
it should fit and the photo should give you an idea how to install it so enjoy this
upgrade.

title: Raspberry Pi Zero Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my Pi Zero Case designed mainly to hold my Pi Zero W , but also works with the normal Pi Zero as well with wifi dongles.

Its designed to allow the Pi to just slide in and the power cord keeps it in place. As it uses a sleeve to hold the Pi it also means it is quite robust and doesnt break mounting lugs and also does not neeed screws or bolts to hold it in.

In addition, the top can take a Neopixel LED ring for added shazam and a rotary encoder as well if you want to have some input.

I've managed as well to fit an I2C audio amp and rectangular speaker inside as well. It all prints easily and the only trick is that i have printed the LED diffuser in PETG with 0% infill.

If you just want it as a case, then you can omit the light ring and I will be adding a knob replacement that is a snug fit so that it all fits nicely.

Hope you like it and it makes a change from the standard flat rectangles.

Also see https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2611073 which has a built in OLED display

I also have an instructable to use this case and a Pi Zero to control mains sockets via Alexa and emulating RF signal required for the plugs.

https://www.instructables.com/id/Alexa-and-Remote-Controlled-Main-Plugs/

Printer:

Malyan M200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

Notes:

It has all been printed in PLA+ at .21875 and 20% infill. The LED diffuser was printed in PETG with 0% infill

The sleeve was a remixed/remixed version - of this original sleeve - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1161310

description.text:
Also any donations would greatly help me: https://www.paypal.me/TerrorBlades
Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/TerrorBlades
So, I was working on project to add props to the Tabletop simulator, so I made this. This is modelled after the image of the Chaos gate game cover.
Each step up to the gate is a square and the hole around the gate is also 28mm so you can place guards there. The Gate is also added as pieces so that you can print them piece by piece and then assemble them! I cant guarantee that they will work but they seam to fit perfectly in Maya! Please tell me if they don't fit and I'll fix it!
This might be added on later!
Edit: I got a suggestion to make a variant where the gate piece can be interchanged. So I made it, There is the Gate frame that has a "lid" and a "portal piece". So, make the Portal frame and lid and then make any number of portal pieces with what ever colors you'd like, multi use! And now with a standing own version with 28mm! Thanks to Donbro for suggesting it!

Stand for holding a surfboard on its side, either for storage or ding repair.

Transparent orange PLA from 3D Supply Source, I don't remember which red filament was used it was either from 3D Supply Source or Atomic Filament (it was printed last year).

comments.text: What's the design intent behind the parallel walls on the cradle surface ? I wouldn't imagine it would make much of a cushioning effect with PLA and would rather tend to just crack. Or is it purely aesthetic and the the single mating surface is plenty sufficient to support the light weight surfboard ?
comments.author: fiveangle

comments.text: It's so the surface can adapt to match the shape/thickness/angle of the rail, so there is a surface in contact, not just a few points.  Most of my boards have a similar construction to an egg, it's very easy to damage if the pressure is concentrated at a point, much stronger when it's distributed over a larger area.  I find PLA tends to creep under light continuous loads instead of crack, the formulations that would crack in this application are probably the same ones that crack when wound on a spool, and I generally avoid those.

print_settings.Notes:: Good luck!
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text: This is a simple GoPro mount I designed for my bike secured using two captive M6 nuts and two M6 socket bolts.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

66%

Notes:

This design requires four extra parts:

  • Two 20mm M6 Bolts
  • Two M6 Locking Nuts

The M6 locking nuts are captive in the design of the each side of the mount, and introduce two challenges for you if you've never printed a part having a metal insert before:

  1. You'll need to ensure that support material is not generated filling the position in which the nut will reside. This is easy to do in Simplify3d, but I'm not sure how such a thing is accomplished using Cura.
  2. You will need to pause your print at the right time so you can insert the locking nut at the layer right before the nut is covered. The instructions for this will vary depending upon what kind of printer you are using and whether it is printing from an SD card or using a tool like OctoPrint, but you can find a variety of tutorial videos on youtube to help you solve this problem.

Good luck!

author: Wademl

title: Laser Cut Raspberry Pi Mini HiFi

description.text:
The system was in two parts, a pair of PC speakers and the Raspberry Pi 3 itself. The cases were made by plywood of 3mm thickness.

[PC speakers]

I designed the speaker cases with this tool, www.makercase.com . It allows you to set the size , draws holes and text. It will automatically generate a svg file for laser cutting.

For the electronics parts, I used two 2” speaker drivers and a speaker cable with amp, usb and 3.5mm plug built-in.

[Raspberry Pi Case]

Originally I designed the case for 3D printing. I found the design also suitable for laser cutting. The upper and lower panel was connected with nylon screws.

I used Raspberry Pi ‘s 3.5mm jack for audio output, usb port to power up the speakers. Of course, you may add a dac expansion board onto the Raspberry Pi to make the audio output even better.

[Software]

Volumio was installed for audio playback. It was a great app that can play local songs, from NAS and Spotify.

It was a simple project that anyone can do it.

author: Wademl

description.text:
I loved the original design, except that I had no M4 screws at the time of printing, and that even then the arms had a little too much play. This fixes both of those problems. It snaps right over both pieces and makes for a very solid experience.

Note: The other pieces such as the barrel and grip are required for this to work.
Note: The holes should fit m2 screws, or, when widened, m3.

Changes:
-Split the model into two pieces. I think I will stick with the rail version, since that allows the parts to be screwed into each other, and removes the primary point of failure, which was the arms snapping as the whole part was stretched over the blaster. This also allows there to be an insert for the rail to be more functional.
-Added a version with a tactical rail, grabbed from bitsandbooks
-Made the whole system easier to print
-Reinforced weak points. My original developed a small crack on the cage that needed to be heated and rejoined.
-Rounded some of the top parts if the cage when I realized that the cage also makes the whole system top prime very well, though it is somewhat uncomfortable.

Update 8/26/2017:
Have made some changes, very much not abandoned. I am printing left and right sides with a screw port right now. Hope it works out!

comments.text: Cheers man, solid part. I had no screws around so I welded mine together using raw filament in the holes and a soldering iron.
comments.author: Flippant

comments.text:
Very nice! I may have to make a solid version at some point. I hope it works well for you.
Also, thank you for posting your print.
comments.author: Flippant

comments.text: You are most welcome. It works really well, and as a plus, makes removing the pump grip easy for transport, as it uses no permanent shell connecting screws. however, the top cage does block access to the jam door sometimes, when I lend my blaster to someone and they don't prime it properly. I have since changed to arms I remixed with carbon fiber on one of my two Recons, your design is still on the other. I recommend it highly.

title: FolgerTech 2020 i3 BL Touch Bracket w/cooling fan for MK9 Extruder

description.text:
A remix of my MK9 Blower mount with servo probe to accept a BL Touch.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1481551

The BL Touch is centered in front of the nozzle (X Axis) and ~37 mm forward (Y Axis) - this allows the BL Touch to not impact glass clips etc during large prints that take up the whole bed.

Note: you may need to increase / decrease the Z position of the BL Touch to get clearance/adjust the Z Axis offset. (my offset is -0.70 mm, YMMV).

The blower nozzle can be found from Hydroslide here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:976189

The fan/blower can purchased from here:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00UJBIAX4

Don't want a fan - use the mount without the fan brackets

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

title: Omega 1.8e Wing section extender: Airfoil SD 7035

description.text:
This is a centre section wing extender for the Omega / Highlight 1.8e glider. This glider is sadly no longer available. The 1.8 metre wing span was fine but if you wanted to extend it to make it an even better floater you could buy a centre section to extend the wing span by around 40cm. They were only available for a short time and many of us didn't get the chance to buy one :(

The airfoil is SD 7035 (I think), matches the existing wing perfectly except for 1mm too long in the trailing edge which is no problem.

Chord is 187mm

The panel is 10cm wide, you can scale the Z axis if you want to print it bigger, I will probably print out 3 and join them.

The spar hole is 8mm for a carbon tube with an inside diameter of 6mm. This is the size of the original wing spar.

This is a solid object, must be printed with around 10% infill. Increase top and bottom layers as necessary.

I have included an extra STL that has some support for the trailing edge of the wing as it tends to lift up a bit off the bed as the print gets higher. NB. I have not tried this STL to see if it works.

EDIT: I added an updated centre section with 4mm bolt holes and servo cable exit hole. Its 60mm, the 2 outer sections are 120mm so its a 300mm extension. You can add as many outer sections as you like.
I also added a 3mm hole towards the trailing edge for alignment purposes.

author: cacvalle

description.text:
This is a remix of the former Better Temperature Tower by Thump2010 in OpenSCAD, fully customizable in temperature steps and range. A generic post-processor script is included - it works on any of the towers "automagically" as long as you set proper initial temperature in the filament settings, and slice at 0.2mm.

The eventual plan for the temperature customizer to extract the settings from the sliced tower (via embedded printed marks).

The generic layer temperature post-processor script for the Better Temperature Tower operates on the G-code generated by Slic3r.

By default, it starts with the printing temperature set in the Filament settings, then decrements it by 5 degrees C for each block of the tower. Its default settings work with any of the Better Temperature Tower models printed at 0.2mm layer height.

It is a more generic and compact replacement for the "tempTowerScript" family of scripts included in the Better Temperature Tower.

For the older, non customizable tower that I used to reverse-engineer the original, see the OnShape document.

Installation

  1. Install perl, e.g. activePerl.

  2. Add the full path to the script to "Print Settings" → "Output options" → "Post-processing scripts".

  3. Add the following to "Printer Settings" → "Custom G-code" → "Before layer change G-code":

    ; Layer [layer_num]
Printing

  1. Print at 0.2mm layer height. If not, multiply the default values of skip and block parameters by (0.2mm/new_layer_height), and add them as start g-code. E.g. if the layer height is 0.1mm, the multiplier will be 0.2mm/0.1mm = 2, and you should add the following "Filament Settings" → "Custom G-Code" → "Start G-Code":

    ; Tower skip 20
; Tower block 70

    See below for further details and for the default values of all the script's settings.

    The plan is to extract the layer heights automatically from the g-code, so this won't be necessary in the future.

  2. If the script has successfully processed the g-code, the g-code file will begin with a line similar to the below:

    ; Processed by tempTowerScript.pl

    If this doesn't happen, then you must debug the script invocation. Make sure that you've installed perl.

  3. If you wish to modify the default settings for the script, add any one or more of the following optional lines to the "Filament Settings" → "Custom G-Code" → "Start G-Code". Those are g-code comments that are interpreted by the script, are optional, and can be added one-by-one as needed. None of those are normally necessary.

    ; Tower temp 222      - set initial temp to 222 (default: temperature set in Filament)
; Tower temp_step -5  - step temperature down 5 degrees for each block
; Tower skip 10       - first block is 10 layers higher than others
; Tower block 35      - the blocks are 35 layers high
; Tower blocks 10     - print only 10 blocks (cut off higher blocks, default: 0 - print all)

description.text:
Hello riders of the waves.  Is your board's wax old?  Could your board do with a little TLC?  Well then print you one of these little guys and get started.
I looked around a while back and noticed that, to my surprise, that there wasn't a basic wax comb for surf boards available on Thingiverse, so here you are.  Its a cheap little thing to start with but I thought it would be cool to be able to customize your own.  So go for it.
Please modify this to fit your tastes.
I included a basic version and a version that I put one of the Buket O' Octopi because I thought that would look cool.  (Note that the one in the picture was one I made for the a guy that helped me pick out my first board.)

• Print
  • Remove worn out old wax as necessary with you new sweet wax comb.
  • Catch the next great day of surf.

comments.text: how do i customize it? and what program did you use to make it? bye the way love it looks awesome!
comments.author: nickerkul

comments.text:
When i customized this I used SketchUp. There is a tool that allows for 3D text. Then I just moved it to the top surface. Then You use an add on to export the STL and print. You can also use Netfabb to clean up the model, or switch to x-ray view to delete any extraneous surfaces inside the comb. Then you just print.
I printed it in ABS as the PLA is a bit brittle for this application and tends to chip versus wear like the softer, tougher ABS.
I hope this helps, and thanks for your comment.

author: bctech7

description.text:
Nintendo's latest entry into the handheld world. This one builds a little differently - you will need a paperclip to finish.

Print all the parts, then straighten a paperclip, and insert it through top.stl, and into the stub on bottom.stl. then snip the other side of the paperclip so it's a little shorter than the width of bottom.stl, and glue cap.stl into bottom.stl to hold everything in place.

It's a bit tricky, but once the glue has completely set, you'll have a working hinge.

title: Chevy Impala Arm Rest Hinge Plate

description.text:
I designed this to replace the plate in the arm rest of my 2000 Chevy Impala used to connect the hinge of the arm rest to the base of the center console. The original plate is designed ridiculously thin for the application and eventually the arm rest hinge tore out. This plate snaps in over top of the remnants of the old plate.

Designed with threaded M5 bolt holes just in case I needed them but It was such a tight fit that no additional screws were needed to keep it in place. It's designed to re-use the screw retains from the original plate, just pop them out of it and into this.

Do not print in PLA. I printed with Hatchbox PETG and it's survived a summer in the car in Phoenix Arizona (so external temps at or near 120 F) so that should cover most earth temps in the higher end.

I've added a DXF of the base plate I extruded from if someone cares to do their own or make one for the case where the old plate is completely removed.

title: Bicycle Chain-Guide
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This Thingi is a Chain-Guide for Bicycles. The Design is based on the c.guide from bionicon.

I just mounted it a few days ago, so i can't say anything about the durability until now (especial the wear from the chain).

After a few weeks of usage, i will post an update here.

Update (28.09.2017):
Uploaded some new Pictures (after ~400km). There are some visible grooves but i think this is ok.

Printer:

Custom Wilson II

Rafts:

No

Notes:

Flexible Part (TPU):

  • 2 Perimeters
  • ~5% trigonometric Infill
  • 5 Bottom/Top Layers
  • no Support

Stiff part (PETG):

  • 4 Perimeters
  • 75% Infill
  • 5 bottom/top Layers
  • Support!
  • maybe POM / Nylon will be the better choice in terms of wear and tear, caused of the chain

Ziptie the flexible part to the chain-stay, bend the stiff part around the chain and connect the two parts with a M3x20 screw. To avoid a breakage of the stiff part while bending, slightly heat it up.

title: Gunpla HG & MG support base set

description.text:
This is an adjustable Gunpla Stand, for both MG and HG (RG certainly). It is also a box with lid for storing unused parts, hands, weapons, etc. Now I need not to worry how to store these tiny little parts.

I printed a MG one for my Macross Delta VF-31J and a HG for my RG RX-78. COOL!

For the hollowed text, you need to custom make for yourself.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/35zIIJXZUGS

Printer:

Cetus 3D

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Select the parts you need.

Print 2 locks to fix the length of the rod.

How to make hollowed text

You can make the text with Tinkercad but you have no font to select.

The hollowed text is made by Inkscape:

https://inkscape.org

For hollowed text, you must choose Stencil family. You can find some free stencil family TTF on WWW.

Convert the TTF text to path. Save the path as SVG file and then import the file to Tinkercad.

Resize and make the text hollow. Finally combine the text with the lid.

author: gloriabachgil

description.text:
Cable protectors for USB Type C cables.

STL files are for original Apple and Xiaomi cables. Fusion 360 archive available for folks who want to customize their own.

There are two types for the Apple version. One which is full-sized, and the other one is slightly shorter for people who have cases on their devices.

3d printed Ball bearing i modified and used in a project, instructable available here: https://www.instructables.com/id/Giant-Fidget-Spinner-3D-Printed/

no assembly required.

Printer:

Creality3D CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I used this for my 19" fidget spinner, instructables available here!!
https://www.instructables.com/id/Giant-Fidget-Spinner-3D-Printed/

Minor tolerance tweak

i printed the original thing at a smaller scale, the fitting was too tight. I scaled down all the balls a little bit, removed a ball. All modification done in blender. Also removed the custom support provided, i ifound that the Cura zigzag support is easier to remove + use less filament.
introduction to friction friction depends on the 3 variables, surface area, magnitude of normal reaction force and the material property called coefficient of friction per unit area!
Design or modify your own ball bearing!! to reduces friction!! an look for where ball bearing are used around you!!

title: Skirmish Wars: Advance Tactics Board Game (24 Pieces)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a set of 24 game pieces needed for the game "Skirmish Wars: Advance Tactics" which is a board game based on the widely known and extremely famous video game by Nintendo "Advance Wars."

Since I could not find these 3D models online I decided to compile my own set of game board pieces specifically for this DIY board game "Skirmish Wars: Advance Tactics", I browsed many different 3D model communities, catalogs, and file share sites, in search for these game pieces and had to individually modify each to fit on a game board.

The game pieces included : (Each are measured to be 0.5 x 0.5 Inches)

  • Infantry
  • Mech
  • Recon
  • APC
  • Tank
  • Artillery
  • Med Tank
  • Rocket
  • AA Missles
  • AA Tank
  • Fighter
  • Bomber
  • T-Copter (Transport Copter)
  • B-Copter (Battle Copter)
  • Cruiser
  • Battleship
  • Sub
  • Lander
  • Building Pieces : City, Headquarters 1 & 2, Factory, Airport, and Ship Yard.

You will have to print your own board to play the game on, to learn how to make your own
S.W.A.T. board game check out the links bellow.

Official Board Game Description Page : https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/40455/skirmish-wars-advance-tactics

Unofficial Wikipedia : http://skirmishwars.wikidot.com/start

I hope someone finds these helpful!

Printer:

Trinus 3D Printer

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Infill:

15

Notes:

-Some of these models have supports added to them already!

title: KingDomino addon

description.text:
English

NEW Added a new box version ( kingdomino_box_2.stl ) that can store the kings. Unfortunately, this new version can no more store the original kings and castles.

I made this because I really love this game, but I was tired of the cardboard castles that comes with this game.

Once I made the castles, I realized that I needed a new box. So I made one that can store the "kings", the castles and a small box to put the castles cardboards appart. I also added a removable rack to allow better cards manipulation.

ADDED : A king !

Still to be done : A new box that can contain the customized kings.

Français

NOUVEAU Ajout d'une nouvelle boite ( kingdomino_box_2.stl ) qui permet de ranger les rois. Par contre, cette novuelle version ne peut plus contenir les rois et chateaux originaux.

J'ai fait cette extension parce que j'adore ce jeu, mais les petits châteaux en carton n'étaient pas terribles.

J'ai aussi refait la boite qui peut contenir les châteaux, les "rois" et une petite boite pour conserver les cartons des châteaux originaux.J'ai ajouté un sabot pour les cartes afin de les prendre plus facilement.

AJOUT : Un roi !

Enre à faire : une boite qui peut contenir les rois personnalisés

Anycubic Mega i3

author: Vracer111

description.text:
Short English description:

This thing allows you to place a cooler in front of a fan, if you have this sort of a prusa i3 clone. Compare the first and the last pictures, to see, how it is used.
Of you are printing with ABS, use ABS for this thing. PLA may melt near the hotend, if you print ABS.
Borders are 1.2 mm, so you can use 0.2 or 0.3 or 0.4 nozzles.
It should work with no infill as well and with 0.2 resolution.
I added the freeCAD-file, if someone like to make it better.

Deutsche ausführlichere Beschreibung:

Da ich für meinen Drucker nichts passendes fand, konstruierte ich dieses Teil.
Das Bauteil lässt sich im Extruder links oder rechts vom Gitter einklemmen, durch das die Lüfterluft bläst.
Bei meinem Drucker geht die Luft nach vorne und blies einem beim Zusehen ins Auge. Am Hotend ist sie jedoch nützlicher. ;-) Das letzte Bild zeigt das Hotend und einen Teil der Lüftungsschlitze ohne den Lüfter.

Ich habe das Teil in drei Varianten eingestellt:
V1: Steg links (von vorne gesehen)
V2: ohne Steg (dann muss ein festgeklebt werden, geht mit Tesastreifen)
V3: Steg rechts
Eine freeCAD-Datei des Lüfters habe ich auch noch eingestellt, falls den jemand verbessern mag.

Stege und Wandteile sind 1,2mm dick, so kann ein Extruder mit 0,2 oder, 0,3 sowie 0,4 Durchmesser genutzt werden.
Sollte mit 0,2 Schichtdicke und ohne Füllung ebenfalls funktionieren.

Meine erste Version ist in PLA gedruckt und funktioniert super für weitere PLA-Drucke.
Wer mit ABS druckt, sollte das Teil besser auch in ABS drucken und verwenden, denn PLA könnte bei den höheren Temperaturen schmelzen.

remixed_from.title: Mini case for LNA4All low noise amplifier for RTL-SDR radio

title: Mini case for LNA4All low noise amplifier for RTL-SDR radio - remix

description.text:
I printed the original vented case version of RandyR's thing but found that the size was a wee bit too small for my LMA4ALL board. This rework increases the internal dimensions slightly as well as increasing the wall thickness in order to provide a little bit more sturdiness. I also amended the clip pieces in order to make them more 3D printer friendly as the originals end up being printed in mid-air at one point.
One thing to watch out for should you also find the fit a bit tight are the points where the circuit board has been snapped away from its neighbours after the manufacturing stage - there can be small sticky out bits which can be carefully filed away.

I have removed the slot for power leads in the original as I power my LNA4ALL using Bias-T from my SDR dongle.

My box was printed using ABS but any plastic will do the job. Note that there is no RF shielding - you may wish to use this box as a starting point for your enclosure project should you require it.

description.text:
Here is a door sign to let people know whether a room is In Use or is Vacant.
I've also added a Dirty / Clean variant for the dishwasher

It is made from 4 parts:

  • 1 x Back Plate which has the text on it
  • 1 x Slider which you move back and forth with your finger
  • 2 x End Plates which press onto the ends of the back plate once the slider has been fitted.

You can fit 12mm double-sided tape to the back of the End Plates to allow you to attach the sign to a door.

To colour the text I paused the Back Plate print at height 5.7mm and changed the filament, then changed back to the original filament at height 6.5mm

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes:

I chose to print the slider face down on a raft to end up with a matt finish and no need for supports.

The end plates are a tight friction fit. You may want to prepare the ends of the back plate before attempting to fit the ends.

Designed in Fusion 360.

I chose to make the model as separate components so they could each be printed without supports.

title: smart effector mount for traxxas rods

description.text:
Mount to allow use of Traxxas rods with the Duet3d smart effector for delta printers. I have been happy with my Traxxas rods, and wanted to try them on the new effector before thinking about magnetic arms.
Seems to be stiff enough and strong enough printed in PETG - a test 2 walled cube with a 0.2mm slice taken out printed sharply, and the faces printed 0.2mm apart separated cleanly.

Update: post11.stl is a slightly modified version for printing in a carbon fibre filament.

Printer:

Kossel XL

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

There is not much room for the nuts and bolts used to fix the rod ends. I have recessed one of the outer holes for a bolt head - this just gives room to tighten the nut on the other bolt. I used a flat headed hex bolt for the mount next to the 8 way connector - there is not much room between the mount and the connector.
FreeCad

comments.text:
Hi
At the carriage end of the rods I am still using the standard kossel carrier - the spacing on the smart effector mount makes the rods parallel with this.
I have recently modified the mount slightly for printing in carbon fibre filament - put a thread inside the holes, so that the m3 bolts tighten really firmly. Also thickened the vertical bit a little. Seem to work well
I will post an updated stl file

title: 85mm GPU fan to 92mm case fan adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The 85mm fans on my GPU started rattling. Rather than taking the plastic shroud off my graphics card and zip-tieing the fans to the cooler, I decided to get a bit of practice in fusion and made this adapter for using 92mm case fans in place of the 85mm fans.

STEP file and mount sketches included to make modifications easier.

As a footnote, if you look at the picture of the card - of course sapphire had to have the third fan mount rotated differently than the other two. Because why not, right? These are the things you'll probably have to accommodate for by modifying this design.
If you want to get fancy, you probably could make the bottom cylinder wall thicker by ~4-6mm, cut off the three-pronged mount part, cut slots into the side of the wall and have keys on the three-prong mount so it freely rotates within the duct without separating.

title: Bracket for Techart Pro LM-EA7 Adapter (w/ Nikon Lens)

description.text:
Techart Pro LM-EA7 Adapter(Techart) is an amazing product that allows vintage lenses supporting auto-focus in Song a7ii series. However, its structure is not strong enough when "heavy" SLR lens are adapted on it. The Lens will tilt downward by gravity and you will hard to get a sharp image. Also, the weak structure affects the focusing stability and accuracy.

This creation has the following objectives:

  • improve stability for heavy lens (Techart + Nikon adapter)
  • provide a more tidy outlook by covering the adapters
  • provide a flat bottom surface so that the camera can be sit on table properly

I may try to improve in future:

  • add bearing between the moving adapter and support
  • add screw holes on bracket to match the 2 screw on Techart

Printer:

the size may not fit everyone.
My approach is try to print a small part of it and try to make adjustment before printout the full object.

The "nut" for holding the lens is printed separately and inserted to the main object.

Installing the the bracket
  1. mount the Techart on a7
  2. mount the Nikon adapter
  3. From the front, push the bracket(with nut inserted) onto the Techart
  4. mount the lens
